content.question:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="P R aqueous, which is red, plus H 2 0 with a positive one charge aqueous, is in equilibrium with H P R with a positive one charge aqueous, which is yellow, plus H 2 O liquid" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtable columnalign="left" rowalign="center" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mtext>PR</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>HPR</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.7em"></mspace><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>d</mi><mtext></mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="8.5em"></mspace><mi>y</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>w</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></math>

Phenol red, <math alttext="P R aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>R</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, is a red compound that has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="555 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>555</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. It reacts with hydronium ions according the equation above, producing water and the acidified form of phenol red, <math alttext="H P R with a positive one charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is yellow and has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="435 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>435 nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

a) Write the <math alttext="K sub e q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> expression for the equilibrium reaction above.

The absorption spectra of an equilibrium mixture of <math alttext="P R, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PR</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H P R with a positive one charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HP</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, collected at two different temperatures, are shown in the following diagram.

frqParts.text:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="P R aqueous, which is red, plus H 2 0 with a positive one charge aqueous, is in equilibrium with H P R with a positive one charge aqueous, which is yellow, plus H 2 O liquid" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtable columnalign="left" rowalign="center" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mtext>PR</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>HPR</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.7em"></mspace><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>d</mi><mtext></mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="8.5em"></mspace><mi>y</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>w</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></math>

Phenol red, <math alttext="P R aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>R</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, is a red compound that has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="555 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>555</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. It reacts with hydronium ions according the equation above, producing water and the acidified form of phenol red, <math alttext="H P R with a positive one charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>P</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is yellow and has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="435 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>435 nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

a) Write the <math alttext="K sub e q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> expression for the equilibrium reaction above.

The absorption spectra of an equilibrium mixture of <math alttext="P R, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PR</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H P R with a positive one charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HP</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, collected at two different temperatures, are shown in the following diagram.

(b) Which peak, the one at <math alttext="435 nanometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>435 nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> or the one at <math alttext="555 nanometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>555 nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, results from the absorption of photons with the greater energy? Justify your answer.
(c) Based on the diagram above, is the forward reaction endothermic or exothermic? Justify your answer in terms of Le Châtelier’s principle.

A calibration plot of the absorbance at wavelength <math alttext="555 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>555 nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> versus the concentration of <math alttext="P R, aqueuous" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>R</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></math> is shown in the following graph.

(d) Based on the best-fit line in the graph, what is the approximate absorbance value for a solution in which <math alttext="the molar concentration of P R equals 2.0 times 10 to the negative 5, molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>PR</mtext><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

(e) A student measures the absorbance of a solution of <math alttext="P R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of unknown concentration in order to determine the <math alttext="molar concentration of P R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>PR</mtext><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution using the calibration plot above. The outside of the cuvette is wiped clean before placing it in the spectrophotometer. Explain why this step is important to ensure an accurate absorbance measurement.

Over time, <math alttext="P R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> converts to a colorless molecule in the presence of <math alttext="O C l with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions. To study the rate of the reaction, the student recorded the absorbance of the <math alttext="P R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution at <math alttext="555 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>555</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in a <math alttext="0.50 molar K O C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution. The temperature and <math alttext="molar concentration of O C l with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>[O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> remain constant throughout the reaction. The results are summarized in the table below.

Time

(<math alttext="in minutes" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>min</mtext><mo>⁡</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>)

Absorbance

0
 0.80

6
 0.63

12
 0.50

18
 0.40

24
 0.32

30
 0.25

36
 0.20

(f) Determine the half-life of the reaction. Include units in your answer.

(g) Explain how the absorbance and time data are consistent with a process that is first order with respect to <math alttext="P R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

A second trial is conducted at the same constant temperature, but with <math alttext="the molar concentration of O C l with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> changed to <math alttext="1.00 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The observed half-life of the reaction is shorter than for the first trial when <math alttext="the molar concentration of O C l with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was <math alttext="0.50 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(h) Explain, in term of particle collisions, why the half-life of the reaction decreases when <math alttext="the molar concentration of O C l with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is changed from <math alttext="0.50 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="1.00 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(i) When <math alttext="the molar concentration of O C l with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is changed from <math alttext="0.50 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="1.00 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, does the magnitude of <math alttext="delta H naught sub reaction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, the enthalpy change of the reaction, increase, decrease, or stay the same? Justify your answer.

In order to prepare the <math alttext="1.00 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="K O C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, a student follows a procedure with the following steps.
Step 1: Measure out <math alttext="45.3 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>45.3 g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="K O C l, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.
Step 2: Add the <math alttext="K O C l, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to a <math alttext="1000.0 milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1000.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> volumetric flask that is half-filled with distilled water and swirl to dissolve.
Step 3: Add enough distilled water to bring the volume up to the line on the flask.
(j) The chemical quantities used in the procedure do NOT produce <math alttext="1.00 molar K O C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Describe specifically how they should be changed in order to produce <math alttext="1.00 molar K O C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(k) Another student is preparing a <math alttext="K O C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution using the correct chemical quantities but notices that some undissolved solid remains at the bottom of the volumetric flask. Under these circumstances, is the concentration of <math alttext="K O C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>OCl</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution in the flask greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="1.00 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>? Explain your answer.

(l) When making the solution above, the student notices that the temperature increases when dissolving <math alttext="K O C l, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>OC</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in water. In a separate experiment, the student dissolves <math alttext="1.0 mol" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>mo</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="K O C l, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>OC</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in <math alttext="1000 decimal point grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1000.</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> each of two different solvents, water and Y. Assuming the enthalpy change is the same regardless of solvent, would the temperature change in water be greater than, less than, or equal to the temperature change in solvent Y? Justify your answer. The specific heat capacities of water and solvent Y are given in the table below.
SolventWater YSpecific Heat Capacity<math alttext="in joules per gram degree Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>J</mtext><mo>/</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>g</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>4.22.2

skill.text: 2.C: Identify experimental procedures that are aligned to a scientific question (which may include a sketch of a lab setup).
